flow.context: Steve Schwab is the Founder & CEO of Casago, a franchise-driven vacation rental PM company that acquired Vacasa in May 2025 and now manages 40,000+ properties across a distributed franchise network. Based in Cannon Beach, OR with HQ in Scottsdale, AZ. They use Guesty as their franchise PMS, have active Breezeway relationships in some locations, and just hired a Chief Digital Officer (David Angotti, Nov 2025) to roll out AI-powered tools across the network. Their Cannon Beach property management page explicitly advertises 'photos with every work order.' Strongest hook for Sam: Cannon Beach is a premier Oregon coast surf town and Sam is a dedicated surfer — plus Casago's franchise model at 40K units creates exactly the distributed inspection quality problem RapidEye solves.

gatekeeper_initial.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper_initial.say: Hey — could you get me through to Steve? It's Sam.
gatekeeper_initial.note: Say it like you know him. Don't volunteer company name or reason. Pause and wait.

branches.label: Asks who's calling / what's this about
He's not available / out of office

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other property management companies on their inspection workflows. Would you mind letting Steve know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Still casual. Don't pitch. You're just a person trying to reach another person.

branches.label: Asks for more detail / company name

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally — it's Sam Parks with RapidEye. We help a couple other property management companies with their turnover inspection workflows. I sent Steve a note recently — would you mind giving him a heads up I'm on the line?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: This is your last gatekeeper attempt. If blocked here, ask for a callback time or direct line.

gatekeeper_unavailable.label: GATEKEEPER — UNAVAILABLE
gatekeeper_unavailable.say: No worries at all. Is there a better time to catch Steve, or a direct line I could try? I don't want to keep bugging the front desk every time.
gatekeeper_unavailable.note: Get a callback time or direct number. If they give you nothing, ask to leave a voicemail. Write down anything they give you.

branches.label: Gives a time or direct number
Won't give info / offers to take a message

gatekeeper_got_info.label: GATEKEEPER — GOT INFO
gatekeeper_got_info.say: Perfect — I really appreciate that. I'll try back then. Thanks for your help.
gatekeeper_got_info.note: Write down exactly what they gave you — time, number, extension. Call back at exactly that time. Set a reminder immediately.

voicemail.label: VOICEMAIL
voicemail.say: Hey Steve — Sam Parks, RapidEye. I work with a few property management companies on their turnover inspection workflows. Given the scale you're running post-Vacasa, thought it'd be worth a quick conversation. My number's [your number]. Again — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Talk soon.
voicemail.note: Under 20 seconds. Don't pitch. Create curiosity. Follow up with an email to steve@casago.com within 5 minutes referencing the voicemail.

opener.label: OPENER — SURF + INDUSTRY HOOK
opener.say: Hey Steve — I actually surf up on the Oregon coast when I'm out that way. Cannon Beach is unreal. But the reason for my call — I work with a few property management companies on their inspection workflows. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard the name tossed around?
opener.note: Feet up on the desk energy. The surf comment is genuine — you've been to Indo, El Sal. Let it land naturally, don't rush it. Pause after 'heard the name tossed around' and let him answer.

branches.label: No / who? / doesn't ring a bell
Bad timing / I'm busy / in a meeting
Immediately hostile / is this a sales call

heard_yes.label: HEARD YES
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let him talk. Whatever he says, agree and bridge to the pain trigger. If he mentions Breezeway or another tool, note it — you'll address it later.

branches.label: Describes what he heard / vaguely recalls
Actually I haven't, was being polite

heard_no.label: HEARD NO — TRANSITION
heard_no.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call is —
heard_no.note: This is just a transition beat. Move directly into the pain trigger. Don't pause here.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING — RESCHEDULE
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow? Or later this week — what works better?
bad_timing.note: Get a specific day and time. Don't accept 'sometime next week.' Pin it down.

reschedule_confirmed.label: RESCHEDULE CONFIRMED
reschedule_confirmed.say: Perfect — I've got that locked in. I'll keep it short. Appreciate it, Steve.
reschedule_confirmed.note: Write it down immediately. Set a reminder. Call at exactly that time. Don't send a calendar invite for a callback — just call.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, I'll own that. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? And you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
permission_fallback.note: Disarm with honesty. Most people respect the transparency and give you 30 seconds. If he says yes, go straight to pain trigger — don't waste a single second.

branches.label: No / not interested / take me off your list

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED — SPLIT
permission_rejected.say: Shoot — totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't on your radar right now?
permission_rejected.note: You're splitting the rejection to find out if it's timing or real disinterest. Most people will clarify. If timing, you get a callback. If disinterest, you get intel.

branches.label: We already have something for this

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER — FRANCHISE SCALE
pain_trigger.say: So I was talking to another CEO running a franchise PM network — not quite your scale but similar model. They'd gone through a big acquisition, brought on a ton of new properties, and the thing that kept coming up was every franchise location was doing turnovers a little differently. Photos were getting taken — that part was fine — but nobody had time to actually review them across that many locations. Guest checks in, finds damage from the last stay, drops a one-star review, and now the owner's calling asking what happened. Worst part? The photo of that damage was sitting in the system the whole time. Somebody just didn't catch it.
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE HERE. Let the silence sit. Let him react to 'somebody just didn't catch it.' This is the moment. If he jumps in, stop talking and listen. If silence, continue to the solution line.

branches.label: Reacts / asks a question / wants to hear more
We already have something for that

pain_solution.label: PAIN — SOLUTION + CTA
pain_solution.say: We built an AI layer that plugs into the turnover photos your teams are already taking — flags damage, missing items, staging problems — no workflow change on their end. Would you be open to taking a look when I'm not ambushing you out of the blue?
pain_solution.note: One sentence on the solution. One sentence CTA. Then STOP. Let him respond. Don't oversell.

branches.label: Interested / tell me more / how does that work
We already do something like this
You should talk to someone else on my team

warm_engaged.label: WARM — STOP PITCHING, ASK QUESTIONS
warm_engaged.say: Yeah absolutely — and honestly I don't want to pitch you blind. Can I ask — with 40,000-plus properties across the franchise network now, how are you thinking about standardizing the inspection process across all those locations?
warm_engaged.note: He's warm. STOP SELLING. Ask questions. Listen for: what tools they use, where the gaps are, who owns the process, what the post-Vacasa integration looks like on the ops side.

branches.label: Mentions David Angotti / CDO / digital tools initiative

discovery_deep.label: DISCOVERY — DIG INTO PHOTO WORKFLOW
discovery_deep.say: That makes a lot of sense. And when a franchisee does a turnover and takes those photos — what happens to them right now? Is someone reviewing every set, or do they mostly just sit there unless there's a complaint?
discovery_deep.note: You're probing for the gap between photos being taken and photos being reviewed. Their Cannon Beach page says 'photos with every work order' — so photos are already part of the process. The question is who's actually looking at them.

branches.label: Acknowledges photos aren't being fully reviewed
Says they have a review process
Not sure / varies by franchise location

discovery_impact.label: DISCOVERY — QUANTIFY THE COST
discovery_impact.say: Yeah — that's exactly what we keep hearing. Out of curiosity, when something does slip through and a guest catches it, what does that typically cost you? Not just the fix, but the review hit, the owner call, the whole chain reaction.
discovery_impact.note: Get him to quantify the cost of missed inspections. At 40K units, even a 1% miss rate is 400 incidents. Let him do the math in his head.

branches.label: It's not that big of a deal honestly
That's why we hired David / building internal tools

discovery_challenge.label: DISCOVERY — PROBE CONSISTENCY
discovery_challenge.say: Got it — and is that review process consistent across all the franchise locations? Or does it kinda depend on the local operator?
discovery_challenge.note: You know the franchise model means inconsistency. Push on the variance between franchisees. That's the gap RapidEye fills.

branches.label: Says it's standardized across the network

discovery_franchise_variance.label: DISCOVERY — FRANCHISE VARIANCE
discovery_franchise_variance.say: Yeah — that's the thing we keep hearing from franchise models. The best operators are totally dialed in, but when you've got 40,000 doors and some locations are doing it one way and others another way, the guest doesn't care whose franchise it is — they see the Casago brand. Is that something you're actively trying to solve right now, or is it more of a down-the-road thing?
discovery_franchise_variance.note: Connect the franchise consistency gap to brand risk. Steve as CEO cares about the Casago brand across all locations. Pause and let him respond.

branches.label: We've got some things in the works
That's more of an ops question / not my day-to-day

breezeway_bridge.label: BREEZEWAY MENTIONED
breezeway_bridge.say: Oh yeah — I know some of your locations have been working with Breezeway. We actually plug right into Breezeway. The way it works is Breezeway captures the photos during the turnover, and our AI analyzes them automatically. So it's not replacing anything — it's just making sure the photos that are already being taken actually get reviewed. Most teams take the photos but nobody has the bandwidth to look at every single set. That's the gap we fill.
breezeway_bridge.note: CRITICAL: position as complementary to Breezeway, NOT a replacement. Casago has Breezeway safety certs and likely uses it in multiple franchises. RapidEye sits on top of what Breezeway already collects.

branches.label: You should talk to Carlos / our CTO about integrations

cdo_bridge.label: CDO / AI TOOLS INITIATIVE
cdo_bridge.say: Yeah — I actually saw you brought David Angotti on as CDO to lead the digital and AI tools rollout. That's exactly the kind of initiative this fits into. We're not asking anyone to change their workflow — it's an AI layer on top of what your teams are already doing. Might be worth getting in front of David too. Would it make sense for me to set something up with both of you, or would you rather I go through David directly?
cdo_bridge.note: The CDO hire (Nov 2025) signals Casago is actively investing in AI tools. Align RapidEye with that initiative. Give Steve the option to include David or delegate — both are wins.

branches.label: Set something up with both of us

cta_meeting.label: CTA — SUGGEST MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Here's what I'd suggest — let me put 20 minutes on the calendar. I'll walk you through what a couple other PM networks are doing with their turnover photos and how the AI analysis actually works. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday open — which works better?
cta_meeting.note: Two specific day options. Don't say 'whenever works.' Pin it down. If he pushes back, pivot to the test drive angle.

branches.label: Picks a day / agrees to meet
I need to loop someone else in

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Perfect — let me lock in [day] at [time]. I'll send the calendar invite right now. It'll be me and my co-founder Rohan — he built the AI side and I handle the ops conversations. Should I send it to steve@casago.com?
book_meeting.note: Confirm the email. Send the invite WHILE ON THE PHONE. Include Rohan. Add a one-liner in the invite description referencing what you discussed. Once booked, STOP SELLING.

branches.label: Include someone else on the invite

meeting_add_attendee.label: ADD ATTENDEE
meeting_add_attendee.say: Absolutely — what's the best email for them? I'll add them to the invite right now.
meeting_add_attendee.note: Get name, title, and email. Likely candidates: John Banczak (COO), Alex Johnson (VP Franchise Ops), Carlos Corzo (CTO), David Angotti (CDO). Write it all down. Likely email pattern: firstname.lastname@casago.com or firstname@casago.com.

meeting_booked.label: MEETING BOOKED — WRAP UP
meeting_booked.say: Awesome — calendar invite's coming your way. Really appreciate you taking my call, Steve. Looking forward to it.
meeting_booked.note: Stop talking. Don't add anything. Don't re-pitch. Send the invite immediately after hanging up. Follow up with a short confirmation email within 10 minutes.

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Especially post-acquisition — I'm sure integrating Vacasa into the network hasn't exactly freed up budget for new tools.
objection_no_budget.note: Agree first. Referencing the Vacasa acquisition shows you did your homework and empathize with their situation. Then split.

split_budget.label: SPLIT — BUDGET
split_budget.say: Just so nobody from my team cold calls you about this again — is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything new right now has to go through a gauntlet to get approved?
split_budget.note: You're separating a hard freeze from a process problem. If it's process, the test drive works. If it's a freeze, plant a seed for next cycle.

branches.label: Approval process is tough right now
It's really just not a priority

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it — I should've assumed you'd be all set. Otherwise you probably would've reached out yourself.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree and lower their guard. Then split to understand the real reason.

split_interest.label: SPLIT — INTEREST
split_interest.say: Just so I don't waste your time — is it that inspection quality isn't really a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate getting cold called?
split_interest.note: Humor helps. Most people laugh at 'hate getting cold called' and soften up. Listen carefully to what they say next — it usually reveals the real objection.

branches.label: Not focused on this / other priorities
Actually we do have some challenges there

objection_have_vendor.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A VENDOR
objection_have_vendor.say: That makes total sense — with 40,000-plus properties you'd have to have something in place. You guys have been doing some stuff with Breezeway, right?
objection_have_vendor.note: You KNOW they have Breezeway relationships. Naming it shows credibility and research. The split will tell you if they're truly happy or just settled.

split_vendor.label: SPLIT — VENDOR
split_vendor.say: Got it. And just so I'm not barking up the wrong tree — is it that you're fully covered and happy with how it's working across the network, or is it more that switching or adding anything new during the integration would just be a headache?
split_vendor.note: Most PM companies 'have' tools but aren't fully satisfied. The split separates real satisfaction from switching friction. If friction, test drive works. If genuinely happy, plant a seed and get a referral.

branches.label: It works but has gaps / not perfect everywhere
Switching is the issue, not satisfaction

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Totally respect that. You're not buying anything today, and I'm not trying to sell you anything today. But here's what I've seen — when budget does free up or priorities shift, the people who move fast are the ones who already know what's on their shortlist. Would you be open to a 20-minute look — not to buy anything, just so it's on your radar? If nothing else I can show you what a couple other franchise PM networks are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas.
sell_test_drive.note: You're selling the meeting, not the product. The 'steal some ideas' line works because it makes the meeting valuable even if they never buy. If still no, try the referral path.

branches.label: Sure / fine / I can do that

sell_test_drive_light.label: PLANT THE SEED — GET REFERRAL
sell_test_drive_light.say: Glad to hear it's working. I'll be honest — we're not trying to replace Breezeway. We sit on top of it. But if it's all covered, I'm not gonna force it. Could I ask though — who on your team runs the ops and inspection side day to day? Just so if we reach out again I'm talking to the right person and not bugging the CEO.
sell_test_drive_light.note: If truly happy, don't push. But get a referral to ops. Ideal targets: Alex Johnson (VP Franchise Ops), John Banczak (COO), Carlos Corzo (CTO), David Angotti (CDO).

branches.label: That would be me / I handle it all
I'd rather you didn't contact anyone

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL — WHO OWNS THIS
referral_ask.say: Totally — you're running the whole ship, I don't want to waste your time in the weeds. Who on your team typically owns the inspection and turnover workflow? Is that more of an ops thing, or does it sit with the tech side?
referral_ask.note: You're fishing for a name. Likely targets: Alex Johnson (VP Franchise Ops), John Banczak (COO), Carlos Corzo (CTO), David Angotti (CDO). If he gives a name, confirm spelling and ask for email or direct line.

referral_ask_fallback.label: REFERRAL — LAST ATTEMPT
referral_ask_fallback.say: No worries at all. Last thing — is there someone on your team who handles the ops or inspection side that I should reach out to? That way I'm not cold calling the CEO next time.
referral_ask_fallback.note: Lighter touch referral ask. You're giving him an easy out that still gets you a name. Even a title helps.

referral_get_name.label: REFERRAL — GET CONTACT INFO
referral_get_name.say: Perfect — and what's the best way to reach them? If I can get an email or direct line, I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands and doesn't look like a generic cold pitch.
referral_get_name.note: Get name, title, email, direct number. Likely email pattern: firstname.lastname@casago.com or firstname@casago.com. Confirm before hanging up. Ask if you can mention Steve pointed you their way.

branches.label: Just find them on the website / LinkedIn

referral_get_name_cdo.label: REFERRAL — CDO (DAVID ANGOTTI)
referral_get_name_cdo.say: David Angotti, right? I saw the announcement about him coming on to lead the digital and AI tools rollout — that's exactly the kind of initiative this fits under. What's the best way to get in front of him? And would it help if I mentioned you pointed me his way?
referral_get_name_cdo.note: Naming David and his role shows deep research. Asking to use Steve's name as a warm intro is powerful — even a casual 'sure' dramatically increases your chances with David.

branches.label: Yes, mention my name / gives contact info
Don't mention me / just reach out cold

referral_get_name_cto.label: REFERRAL — CTO (CARLOS CORZO)
referral_get_name_cto.say: Carlos Corzo? Got it. I know he's also behind Guest Ranger on the AI side — this is right in his wheelhouse. What's the best way to reach him? And is it cool if I mention you pointed me his direction?
referral_get_name_cto.note: Naming Carlos and Guest Ranger (his AI guest screening company) shows deep research. Get permission to use Steve's name. Carlos's known emails: carlos@casago.com, carlos.corzo@casago.com. Known phone: 602-679-3655.

branches.label: Gives contact info / OK to use his name
Just reach out to him directly

referral_use_name.label: REFERRAL — ASK TO USE STEVE'S NAME
referral_use_name.say: Awesome — and is it cool if I mention you pointed me their way? Just so it doesn't land like another cold call.
referral_use_name.note: Getting permission to use Steve's name turns your next call from cold to warm. Even a vague 'sure' counts.

branches.label: I'd rather you didn't / just reach out

referral_confirm.label: REFERRAL — CONFIRM AND CLOSE
referral_confirm.say: Really appreciate that, Steve. I'll reach out to them this week and keep it relevant. And hey — next time I'm surfing Cannon Beach I'll let you know. Thanks for your time.
referral_confirm.note: End warm. The surf callback makes you memorable. Send Steve a thank-you email within an hour. Reach out to the referral within 24 hours using Steve's name if he gave permission.

objection_send_email.label: SEND EMAIL — REDIRECT
objection_send_email.say: Totally fair. One quick question before I do —
objection_send_email.note: Don't just accept 'send me an email' and hang up. Bridge to the question that gets you intel and keeps the conversation alive for 30 more seconds.

send_email_question.label: SEND EMAIL — ASK WHAT MATTERS
send_email_question.say: What would be most relevant to include? I don't wanna just blast you a generic deck. Is it more about how it works technically, how it plugs into your current stack, or what the ROI looks like at franchise scale?
send_email_question.note: This does two things: gets intel on what he cares about, and keeps the conversation going. Whatever he says, tailor the email to exactly that.

send_email_confirm.label: SEND EMAIL — CONFIRM ADDRESS
send_email_confirm.say: Got it — I'll send that over today. Should I use steve@casago.com? And I'll toss in a couple times to chat next week in case anything catches your eye.
send_email_confirm.note: Confirm the email address. Include 2 specific time slots in the email. Subject line should reference this call: 'Turnover photo analysis for Casago franchise network — following up from our call.'

send_email_exit.label: EMAIL CONFIRMED — WRAP UP
send_email_exit.say: Perfect. Appreciate you taking my call, Steve. You'll have it in your inbox today.
send_email_exit.note: Send the email within 1 hour. Personalize: reference Vacasa acquisition, franchise scale, and whatever he said on the call. Include 2 time slots. Follow up in 3 business days if no reply. Add to a 2-week email cadence.

graceful_exit.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
graceful_exit.say: Totally understand. If anything changes, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Steve.
graceful_exit.note: Don't burn the bridge. Send a brief follow-up email anyway: 'Hey Steve, appreciate you taking my call. If inspection quality across the franchise network ever becomes a priority, happy to show you what we're building. — Sam.' Add to 90-day follow-up cadence.
